English.defintion: Marketing expenses used in mutual funds. This is the cost charged for promotion, marketing, and sales.

401(k) plans are retirement plans that some private corporations offer their employees. A 403(b) plan is similar to a 401(k), but is offered to employees of some nonprofit organizations. In both types of plans, you choose to deduct part of our paycheck and place it into the investment strategy you design. The plans allow you to choose different types of investments, depending on how much risk you want to take. The money you place into the account lowers your taxable income. The employer usually matches a portion of your contribution, sometimes up to 50 percent. The funds grow tax-free until the money is withdrawn during retirement.
Inventory management technique that divides inventory into three groups - A, B, and C, in descending order of importance and level of monitoring, on the basis of the dollar investment in each.
The ability of a firm to make the payment required on a scheduled basis over the life of a debt.

lang.Spanish: Capacidad de cumplimiento del servicio de la deuda

English.defintion: Cost method that includes all manufacturing costs - direct materials, direct labor, fixed and variable indirect costs - and how each part contributes to the final product.
Depreciation method in which depreciation during the first years of the life of the asset is performed in large quantities - decreasing the depreciation costs in later years.
The evaluation of capital expenditure proposals to determine whether they meet the firm's minimum acceptance criterion.
The place where increases and decreases in dollar amounts are noted for each part of a business transaction.

Person qualified to register the operations that are carried out, implement systems to continue in the registration of business operations, provide reports or documents that reflect the financial situation of the business, as well as create resolutions required by the administration of the business.
Obligations or debts that result from the buying of goods or services on credit.
Management by the firm of the time that elapses between its purchase of raw materials and its mailing payment to the supplier.
Amount that clients owe the business from the sale of goods or services that the business offered on credit.

Before opening an account, most banks will review your history of using checking accounts through companies such as TeleCheck or ChexSystems. Some banks will run a full credit report to determine the level of risk. The account information is collected from financial institutions. If you have a history of bouncing checks or misusing your accounts, financial institutions may not open an account for you.
In preparation of financial statements, recognizes revenue at the time of sale and recognizes expenses when they are incurred.
Liabilities for service received for which payment has yet to be made.
Amount that clients owe the business from the sale of goods or services that the business offered on credit.
Revenue recognized in the books before it is received.
Total depreciation valued for a fixed asset which decreases the value of the asset over the number of years of life assigned to the asset.
Preauthorized electronic withdrawal from the payer's account and deposit into the payee's account via a settlement among banks by the automated clearinghouse, or ACH.
Measure the speed with which various accounts are converted into sales or cash - inflows or outflows.
All executive costs associated with the general administration of an organization.
Net quantity cash earned after taxes. The net quantity is determined by multiplying the cash rate by (1-tax rate).

lang.Spanish: Beneficios a ganancias después de impuestos

English.defintion: Net inflow amount resulting of cash expenses deducted after taxes; this is the net amount after taxes have been discounted. The quantity is determined by multiplying the expenses times (1-tax rate).

English.word: After-tax proceeds from sale of old asset
English.defintion: The difference between the old asset's sale procedes and any aplicable taxes or tax refunds related to its sale.

lang.Spanish: Beneficios después de impuestos de la venta de un activo antiguo

English.defintion: The costs borne by stockholders to minimize agency problems.
The likelihood that managers may place personal goals ahead of corporate goals.
A funding strategy under which the firm funds its seasonal requirements with short-term debt and its permanent requirements with long-term debt.
A credit-monitoring technique that uses a schedule that indicates the percentages of the total accounts receivable balance that have been outstanding for specified periods of time.

lang.Spanish: Determinación de la antigüedad de las cuentas por cobrar

English.defintion: Abnormal return measured from the CAPM required rate of return. This abnormal return can be positive, if alpha is greater than zero or negative if alpha is less than zero.
Claims issued by U.S. banks representing ownership of zares of a foreign company's stock held on deposit by the U.S. bank in the foreign market and issued in dollars to U.S. investors.

The USA's third-largest stock exchange. In 2008 it was acquired by the NYSE and became the NYSE Amex Equities in 2009. The AMEX is located in New York City and handles about 10% of all securities traded in the U.S.
Decrease in value that an intangible asset undergoes, and the application of this expense in proportion to the value and time.
Wealthy individual investors who do not operate as a business but invest in promising early-stage companies in exchange for a portion of the firm's equity.
The requirment that for a cerain number of days during the year bourrowers under a line of credit carry a zero loan balance (that is, owe the bank nothing.)

The nominal annual rate of interest, found by multiplying the periodic rate by the number of periods in 1 year, that must be disclosed to consumers on credit cards and loans as a result of “truth-in-lending laws.”

The APR is a measure of the cost of your loan expressed as a yearly percentage rate, such as 10% or 11%. The APR is the rate of interest you are charged, expressed as a yearly rate. If you plan to keep a balance on your credit card account, you want to look for a low APR. If you expect to pay your bills in full each month, it will be more important to compare the annual fee and other charges.
The effective annual rate of interest that must be disclosed to consumers by banks on their savings products as a result of “truth-in-savings laws.”

APY is the amount of interest you will earn on a yearly basis expressed as a percentage. The APY includes the effect of compounding. When comparing different accounts, you should compare the APYs of the savings products, not the interest rates. The higher the APY, the higher the interest you will receive.

lang.Spanish: Rendimiento porcentual anual (APY, por sus siglas en inglés)

English.defintion: A stream of equal periodic cash flows, over a specified time period. These cash flows can be inflws of returns earned on investments or outflows of funds invested to eran future returns.
An annuity for whcih the cash flow occurs at the beginning of each period.
A professional opinion about the monetary value of an asset in the market.
Costs incurred for identifying defective products before the products are sent to the client.
Profits retained and set aside for a specific use by the organization, and the shareholders are informed that these profits will not be distributed as dividends.

In economics and finance, arbitrage is the practice of taking advantage of a price differential between two or more markets: striking a combination of matching deals that capitalize upon the imbalance, the profit being the difference between the market prices. The process of purchasing and selling the identical products, such as foreign exchange, stocks, bonds and other commodities, in several markets intending to make profit from the difference in price. Arbitrage is generally seen as a "risk-less" transaction.
Multifactor asset pricing model that allows market betas to represent only one of the firm's many risk factors.

lang.Spanish: Teoria de varios factores de Mercado

English.defintion: Sum of investment returns divided by number of periods or securities.
An application that presents a business to the state in which it is incorporated.
The griten contract used to formally establish a business partnership.
Lowest Price an investor will accept to sell.
Number of shares offered by current sellers.
An asset is anything owned by a person or organization having monetary value.
Assets represent all the goods and rights on property that a business has (rights on property is just one part of assets…reword?).
Process of diversifying an investment portfolio across various asset categories, such as stocks, bonds, and cash.
The situation in which managers of a firm have more information about operation and future prospects than do investors.
Option whose strike price equals the current market price of the underlying asset.
Public sale through open bidding.
An unbiased examination and evaluation of the financial statements of an organization. An audit verifies that a business abides by the generally accepted accounting principles.
The number of zares of common stock that a firm's corporate charter allows it to issue.
The maximum number of stocks that the state authorizes a business.

This is a computer where you can deposit, withdraw, or transfer money from one account to another 24 hours a day. Use of an ATM requires a card issued by the bank and a personal identification number (PIN). A PIN is a special password or set of numbers to use your debit or ATM card. The PIN is used for security purposes, so no one else can access your account. You can use the ATM for many services, but there might be a fee involved. Most people use the ATM to get cash from their account. If you use another bank's ATM, you might be charged an additional fee. Generally, you can only make deposits at your bank's ATM.
Average number of days' sales in inventory.
The average amount of time hended to pay accounts payable.
The average amoun of time hended to pay accounts payable.
A firm's taxes divided by its taxable income.
Commissions paid when a fund is sold.
Backward-looking analysis.
Inverted market in which futures prices are lower in distant delivery months.
Accounts receivable that have not been liquidated, whose balance is an expense of sales to credit. A debt that is not collectable and therefore worthless to the creditor.
Balance is the amount of money you have in your bank account.
This will determine how your interest is calculated. There are a variety of methods. The most common is the average daily balance.

lang.Spanish: Método para el Cálculo del Saldo

English.defintion: Accounting document that presents the financial situation of a business on a determined date, and clearly shows in detail the value of each asset and liability, as well as capital value (owner's equity).

A balloon mortgage is a large payment at the end of your loan term. This is often after a series of low monthly payments. A balloon mortgage generally offers very low rates for an initial period of time (usually 5, 7, or 10 years). After the period ends the entire balance is due. Many borrowers pay the balance by refinancing their mortgage.
A bank is a business that offers you a place to keep your money and uses it to make more money. Banks offer you different services for keeping your money.
Interest amount charged by the bank when it accents the charge of discounted payments of the client. It also indicates the anticipated interest payment when the bank provides a loan.
Analysis that shows the difference between the bank account balance and the balance on the business' books.
Time drafts drawn on and accepted by banking institutions.
The simplest type of probability distribution; shows only a limited number of outcomes and associated probabilities for a given event.
100 deun uno porciento (por ejemplo, 50 puntos de base es .5 porciento)./1/100th of 1 percent (e.g., 0.5 percent is 50 basis points).
Chance of adverse change in the futures—spot market price relationship.
Bonds with ownership defined by possession.
A study of cognitive errors and emotions in financial decisions.
A diversified portfolio of similar risk or investment style used as a comparison.
A type of cross-sectional analysis in which the firm's ratio values are compared to tose of a key competitor or group of competitors that it wishes to emulate.
The sensitivity of a security's returns to the systematic market risk factor.
A relative measure of nondiversifiable risk. An index of the degree of movement of an asset's return in response to a change in the market return.
Highest price an investor is willing to pay.
Gap between the bid and ask prices that represents a cost to the investor.
Number of shares sought by current buyers.
A model in which a given number of time steps between the valuation date and option expiration are assumed. The underlying stock price can change only to two levels at any time step.
The belief, in support of dividend relevance theory, that investors see current dividends as less risky than future dividends or capital gains.

lang.Spanish: Argumento mas vale pájaro en mano

English.defintion: Formula used to calculate economic values for options on teh basis of continuous time assumptions and return distributions.
Group elected by the firm's stockholders and having ultimate authority to guide corporate affairs and make general policy.
Long-term debt instrument used by business and government to raise large sums of money, generally from a divers group of lenders.

When you purchase a bond, you are essentially loaning money to a corporation or to the government for a certain period of time, called a term. The bond certificate promises the corporation or government will repay you on a specific date with a fixed rate of interest.
Bond interest rate expressed as a percentage of par value.

lang.Spanish: Tasa de Voucher de un Bono

English.defintion: Securities firms and Banks that act as financial intermediaries between bond issuers and investors.
A legal document that specifies both the rights of the bondholders and the duties of the issuing corporation.
Individuals and institutions that purchase bonds for interest income and long-term capital gains.
The fund that establishes the provision of cash payment of a bond to the bondholder at the moment of expiration.
Simultaneous sale and purchase of fixed-income securities to achieve some investment purpose.
Ledger where orginal book entries are transferred.

lang.Spanish: Libro de entradas o asiento final

English.defintion: The strict accounting value of an asset, calculated by subtracting its accumulated depreciation from its installed cost.

The amount per share of common stock that would be received if all of the firm's assets were sold for their exact book (accounting) value and the procedes remaining after paying all liabilities (including preferred stock) were divided among the common stockholders.
Weights that use accounting values to measure the proportion of each type of capital in the firm's financial structures.
The machine or process that limits full capacity of operation.
A branch manager is the person who supervises the bank operations and helps fix problems that cannot be solved by other bank workers.
Number of years over which the conversion premium can be recovered by the increased income of the senior security over the junior security.
The level of total new financing at which the cost of one of the financing components rises, thereby causing an upward shift in the weighted marginal cost of capital (GMC.)
Indicaties the level of operations necessary to cover all operating costs and the profitability associated with various levels of sales
A mortgage broker helps a prospective borrower shop around for the best rate and terms in obtaining mortgage financing.
Interest rate charged to investors using margin debt.
Formal information of future plans, usually expressed in monetary terms.
Process of planning future comercial actions and expressing these in a formal plan.
Difference between the real indirect fixed costs incurred uring the period and the indirect fixed costs planned in the budget.
Purchase of a low-strike price call and the simultaneous sale of another, high-strike price call on the same underlying equity with the same expiration date.
Rhythmic pattern of contraction and expansión in the overall economy.
The risk to the firm of being unable to cover operating costs.
Exchange of goods, services, or money rights between economic entities in order to receive financial gain.
Buy order that is to be held until the market price rises to a specified stop price.
Added commission paid by buyer.
Right to buy.
Amount of time before a newly issued bond is callable.
Contractual authority that allows the issuer to redeem bonds prior to scheduled maturity.
A bond that can be redeemed by the issuer prior to its maturity. Usually a premium is paid to the bond owner when the bond is called.

lang.Spanish: Bonos redimibles antes de su vencimiento

English.defintion: Preferred stocks can be removed from the market by paying a specified amount to this preferred stock holders, including unpaid dividends.

lang.Spanish: Acciones preferentes redimibles a su vencimiento

English.defintion: A feature included in nearly all corporate bond issues that gives the issuer the opportunity to repurchase bonds at a stated call price prior to maturity.
The amount by which a bond's call price excedes its par value.
The stated price at which a bond may be repurchased, by sue of a call feature, prior to maturity.
Checks cancelled by the bank and deducted from the account of the customer during the month. They are called cancelled checks because they have been stamped indicating they have been cancelled.
Method for predicting how investment returns are determined in an efficient capital market.

lang.Spanish: Modelo Para Valorar Activos de Capital

English.defintion: Linear risk-return trade-off for all investment portfolios.

Caps are provisions of an adjustable rate mortgage, which limit how much the interest rate can change at each adjustment period or over the life of the loan. A payment cap limits how much the payment due on the loan can increase or decrease.
The long-term funds of a firm; all items on the right-hand side of the firm's balance sheet, excluding current liabilities
Describes the relationship between the required return, ks, and the nondiversifiable risk of the firm as measured by the beta coefficient, b.

lang.Spanish: Modelo de valuación de activos de capital [CAPM]

English.defintion: Budget that covers the acquisition of land, buildings, and fixed assets; the budget can be planned 30 years or more in the future.
the process of evaluating and selecting long-term investments that are consistent with the firm's goal of maximizing owner wealth.
Five distinct but interrelated steps: proposal generation, review and analisis, decisión making, implementation, and follow-up.

lang.Spanish: Proceso de preparación del presupuesto de capital

English.defintion: Loss of the market share as a consequence of the obsolete technology of products and operations.
An outlay of funds by the firm that is expected to produce benefits over a period of time greater than 1 year.
The amount by which the sale price of an asset excedes the asset's initial purchase price.
Leasing that essentially has the same efect between the rentor and land
A market that enables suppliers and demanders of long-term funds to make transactions.
The financial situation in which a firm has only a fixed number of dollars available for capital expenditures, and numerous projects compete for these dollars.
Represents the participation that shareholders have in the activities of a business.
The mix of long-term debt and equity maintained by the firm.

English.word: Carrying Amount of the Bonds Payable
English.defintion: Net value of the bonds at the time they were registered on the books; equals the value of the bond minus the discount paid off or plus the premium amortization.

lang.Spanish: Valor neto en libros de bonos a pagar

English.defintion: Difference between the sum of the lease payments remaining minus the discounts that have been paid off.

lang.Spanish: Valor neto en libros del arrendamiento

English.defintion: Value of the note minus the discount paid off.

lang.Spanish: Valor neto en libros de documentos

English.defintion: The variable costs per unit of holding an item in inventory for a specific period of time.
Legal tender or coins that can be used in exchange goods, debt, or services. Sometimes also including the value of assets that can be converted into cash immediately, as reported by a company.
Recognizes revenues and expenses only with respect to actual inflows and outflows of cash.
Cash paid to management for achieving certain performance goals.
A statement of the firm's plannned inflows and outflows of cash that is used to estimate its short-term cash requirements.
The process used by the firm to bring lock box and other deposits together into one bank, often called the concentration bank.
The amount of time a firm's resources are tied up; calculated by subtracting the average payment period from the operating cycle.
All outlays of cash by the firm during a given financial period.
A percentage deduction from the pruchase price; available to the credit customer who pays its account within a specified time.
The number of days after the beginning of the credit period durnig which the cash discount is available.

lang.Spanish: Periodo de descuento por pronto pago

English.defintion: An item on the balance sheet that reports the value of a company's assets that are cash or can be converted into cash immediately.
All of a firm's inflows of cash in a given financial period.
Short-term money market instruments.
Option that entails the promise of a cash payment based on the difference between market and exercise prices.

CDs are accounts where you leave your money for a set period of time, such as six months, one, two, or five years, called a term. You usually earn a higher rate of interest than in a regular savings account. The longer you promise to keep your money in a CD, the higher the interest rate. Be sure to think about your cash needs before opening a CD because you will pay a penalty if you withdraw your money early.
Finance professional who helps individuals identify and meet financial needs.
The difference between a change in current assets and a change in current liabilities.

lang.Spanish: Cambio en el capital de trabajo neto

English.defintion: A checking account is an account that lets you write checks to pay bills or to buy goods. The financial institution takes the money from your account and pays it to the person named on the check. The financial institution sends you a monthly record of the deposits made and the checks written.
First and largest commodities exchange.
U.S. options market pioneer.
Largest futures Exchange in the United States.
Illege broker-initiated trading in client accounts to generate commission income.
Rules for halting securities trading in volatile markets.
The general balance that shows the assets and liabilities grouped in subdivisions.
The time between deposit of a payment and when spendable funds become available to the firm.
Institutions that ensure balance in the number of futures and futures option contracts bought and sold and that give fulfillment guarantees.
The argument that a firm attracts shareholders whose preferences for the payment and stability of the firm itself.
Investment companies that issue a fixed number of shares at a given point in time.
All common stock of a firm owned by a small group of investors (such as a family.)
Closing costs are various charges associated with the transfer of property. The lender must disclose these costs to you.
A club account is a type of savings account you “join” to save money for a special reason, such as holidays or family vacations. Club accounts usually require you to make regular deposits.
A measure of relative dispersions that is useful in comparing the risks of assets with differing expected returns.
Upper and lower limits on the interest rate paid on floating-rate notes or adjustable-rate mortgages.

o bonos que son propiedad del emisor. El derecho es sobre los beneficios de las acciones y/o el colateral del bono; si no se le satisface totalmente, el prestamista se convierte en un acreedor general./Secured by stock and/or bonds that are owned by the issuer. CLAI si no procedes Prom. stock and/or bond collateral; if not fully satisfied, the lender becomes a general creditor.
A form of financing consisting of short-term, unsecured promissory notes issued by firms with a high credit standing.
The fee that is normally charged on a revolving credit agreement; it often applies to the average unused balance of the borrower's credit line.

lang.Spanish: Comisión de compromiso o por disponibilidad

English.defintion: Costs that are difficult to adjust and are related to the investment of plant and equipment, and other basic structural organization parts of a company.

A company financial statement that displays all items as percentages of a common base figure. This type of financial statement allows for easy analysis between companies or between time periods of a company.
An income statement in which each item is expressed as a percentage of sales.

lang.Spanish: Estado de resultados de formato común

English.defintion: The purest and most basic form of corporate ownership.
A required checking account balance equal to a certain percentage of the amount borrowed from a bank under a line-of-credit or revolving credit agreement.

Compensating factors are favorable factors that might outweigh the negative factors. For example, a borrower has high ratios, but he or she balances this with a good credit history and extra cash in a savings account.
Capital structure that includes pending rights and options to buy ordinary or convertible common stock.
Interest that is earned on a given deposit and has become part of the principal at the end of a specified period.
System where computers are linked together, and different computers have access to the same program and the same data.
A condominium is an apartment building or multiple-unit housing area in which the living units are owned individually.
Indicator of investor mood based on bond yields.
Conflicts in the ranking given a project by NPV and IRR, resulting from differences in the magnitude and timing of cash flows.
A funding strategy under which the firm funds both its seasonal and its permanent requirements with long-term debt.
The owner of a good that send another person to take charge of the sale.
A widely cited dividend valuation approach that asumes that dividends will grow at a constant rate, but a rate that is less than the required return.
Asumes that the value of a share of stock equals the present value of all future dividends (assumed to grow at a constant rate) that it is expected to provide over an infinite time horizon.

lang.Spanish: Modelo de valuación de crecimiento constante [Gordon]

English.defintion: A dividend policy based on the payment of a certain percentage of earnings to owners in each dividend period.

lang.Spanish: Política de razón de pago de dividendos constante

English.defintion: Persistance of the underlying bullish or bearish trend signal.
Practice of preparing budgets for future periods and revising these budgets at the end of each period. The budgets always cover the same number of years.
Compounding of interest an infinite number of times per year at intervals of microseconds.
The workers perform their own inspections to the extent that they each move up the line at the flor of the production.
A probability distribution showing all the possible outcomes and associated probabilities for a given event.
An account on the balance sheet of a corporation or entity that offsets the balance of a related and corresponding account.
Length of time between the date that an option contract is established and the date of its expiration.
Type of interest specifically for a bond contract; it is applied to the par value of a bond in order to determine the amout of interest that should be paid each year.

lang.Spanish: Contrato de tipo de interés de bonos

English.defintion: Investment strategy based on the premise that investors can profit by betting against the overly emotional crowd; strategy to select unpopular stocks.
The portion of a corporation's capital that represents the investment of shareholders in the corporation. Also called contribution of capital.
The format of costs that are separated ender fixed and variable categories instead of being separated by function of production, sales, or administration.
A cost accounting concept calculated as total revenue from a product or service less the total variable cost.
The strategic use of mailing points and bank accounts to lengthen mail float and clearing float, respectively.
The firm's chief accountant, who is responsible for the firm's accounting activities, such as corporate accounting, tax management, financial accounting, and cost accounting.

A convenience check is a cash advance that is used like a regular check. However, the money is charged against your credit limit. There is usually no grace period, and the finance charge is usually higher than for purchases.
An initial outflow followed only by a series of inflows.

lang.Spanish: Patrón de flujo de efectivo convencional

English.defintion: A conventional loan is a mortgage that is not guaranteed, insured, or made by the federal government.
A feature of convertible preferred stock that allows holders to change each share into a stated number of shares of common stock.

lang.Spanish: Cláusula de conversión de una acción preferente

English.defintion: A feature of convertible bonds that allows bondholders to change each bond into a stated number of shares of common stock.
Debt that can be exchanged into more junior securities.
Sensitivity of modified duration to changes in yield to maturity.
A long-term debt instrument indicating that a corporation has borrowed a certain amount of money and promises to repay it in the future under clearly defined terms.
An artificial being created by law (often called a “legal entity”)
A measure of the degree of correlation between two series.
A statistical measure of the relationship between any two series of numbers representing data of any kind.

English.word: Cost of a new issue of common stock
English.defintion: The cost of common stock, net of underpricing and associated flotation costs.

lang.Spanish: Costo de una nueva emisión de acciones ordinarias

English.defintion: The rate of return that a firm must earn on the projects in which it invests to maintain its market value and attract funds.
The rate at which investors discount the expected dividends of the firm to determine its share value.

lang.Spanish: Costo del capital en acciones ordinarias

English.word: Cost of giving up a cash discount
English.defintion: The implied rate of interest paid to delay payment of an account payable for and additional number of days.

lang.Spanish: Costo de renunciar a un descuento por pronto pago

English.defintion: The after-tax cost today of raising long-term funds through borrowing.

lang.Spanish: Costo de una deuda a largo plazo

English.defintion: The new outflow necessary to acquire a new asset.

The ratio of the preferred stock dividend to the firm's net proceeds from the sale of preferred stock; calculated by dividing the annual dividend, by the net proceeds from the sale of the preferred stock..
The same as the cost of an equivalent fully subscribed issue of additional common stock, which is equal to the cost of common stock equity.
Chance that a counterparty to a futures contract obligation will not fulfill his or her obligation.
Bond with tangible interest vouchers.
Interest vouchers.
The percentage of a bond's par value that will be paid annually, typically in two equal semiannual payments, as interest.
An absolute measure of comovement that varies bewteen plus and minus infinity, +∞ and -∞.
Return borrowed shares.
Ratios that measure the firm's ability to pay cerain fixed charges.
Simultaneous purchase of a stock and sale of a call option on that same security.
The ongoing review of a firm's accounts receivable to determine whether customers are paying according to the stated credit terms.
The number of days after beginning of the credit period until full payment of the account is due.
Chance of loss due to issuer default.
Chance of loss due to the inability of a bond issuer to make timely interest and principal payments.
Companies that grade the quality of debt issues.

A credit selection method commonly used with high-volume/small dollar credit requests; relies on a credit score determined by applying statistically derived weights to a credit applicant's scores on key financial and credit characteristics.
The firm's minimum requirements for extending credit to a customer.
The terms of sale for customers who have been extended credit by the firm.
A nonprofit financial institution owned by people who have something in common. You have to become a member of the credit union to keep your money there.
Comparison of different firms' financial ratios atr the same point in time; involves comparing the firm's ratios to tose of other firms in its industry or to industry averages.
The sum of abnormal returns over some event-interval period, typically of one, two, or three days.
Loss potential tied to changing relative values of world currencies.
Expenses of converting host-country currency into the domestic currency of the buyer or seller.
Short-term assets, expected to be converted into cash within 1 year or less.
Short-term liabilities, expected to be paid within 1 year or less.
A measure of liquidity calculated by dividing the firm's current assets by its current liabilities.
Bond's promised interest payment divided by its current purchase price.

English.word: Customer Service Representative or New Account Officer
English.defintion: The customer service representative is the person who can help you open your account. The representative explains services, answers general questions, refers you to a person who can help you, and provides written information explaining the bank products.

lang.Spanish: Representante de Servicio al Cliente u Oficial de Cuentas Nuevas

English.defintion: Time required to tranfer direct material into product.
Adjustment factor used to account for stock splits.
Set by the firm's directors, the date on which all persons whose names are recorded as stockholders recieve a declared dividend at a specified future time.
Method for calculating interest rates, usually 30 days per month and 360 days per year.
Unsecured debt.
Unsecured bonds that only creditworthy firms can issue. Claims are the same as those of any general creditor. May have other unsecured bonds subordinated to them.
The left side of a T-Account or the part that increases the asset balances or decreases the liabilities and owner's equito balance.

A debit card is a plastic card sometimes called a “Check Card.” The debit card has a MasterCard or Visa logo and a magnetic strip on the back that allows you to pay for goods and services at stores and other businesses that accept MasterCard or Visa credit cards. When you use a debit card, the money comes out of your bank account immediately. The bank might give you a debit card that also functions as an ATM card. With a debit card, you can make deposits to or withdrawals from your checking account at ATMs. Some debit card uses might require a PIN if you use the card as an ATM card.
.Memorando that sends notification to the recipient that the debit has been recorded in the account books.
All long-term borrowing incurred by a firm, including bonds.

lang.Spanish: Pasivo a largo plazo o capital de deuda

English.defintion: Long-term debt divided by total assets.
A perosn or company that owes money to a business.
Measures the proportion of total assets financed by the firm's creditors.
Process of choosing a racional option and rejecting the alternative.
A behavioral approach that uses diagrams to map the various inverstment decision alternatives and pay offs, along with their probabilities of occurrence.

These are the most common credit card fees. There might be others. Be sure to read the disclosures with your credit card agreement. •Annual fee. Some companies charge annual fees for the privilege of using their credit cards. Most cards that offer rewards (for example, airline miles or travel awards) charge a yearly fee. •Balance transfer fee. You might be charged for moving balances from one credit card to another. This fee is usually a percentage of the balance transferred. It might have a minimum and a maximum limit. •Cash advance fee. When you access cash through an automatic transfer machine (ATM) with your credit card, you are usually charged a transaction fee. The advance often carries a higher interest rate than regular purchases. •Late fee. Payment must be received -- not postmarked -- on the due date to avoid a late fee. If you are mailing a payment, send it five days before it is due to avoid a late fee. A typical charge is $29 per late payment. •Over-the-limit fee. This fee is applied if your outstanding charges exceed your credit limit. The fee is typically $20. Financial institutions charge different fees for different services. For example, a monthly maintenance fee might be charged for keeping your account open. In addition, you might also be charged a penalty fee if you misuse your account, such as by bouncing a check. Example: One of the participants in an earlier class used a check-cashing store to cash her checks. She cashed four checks a month and was charged $5 each time. That means she paid $20 a month (4 x $5) or $240 a year ($20 x 12 months) just to cash her checks. In comparison, another participant had an account at a bank that charged a monthly fee of $5, which included 8 free checks per month and free use of the ATM. Additionally, ordering a box of 100 checks cost her about $18, since she purchased the checks through the bank. In this case, using a checking account for one year cost her $78 ($5 x 12 months = $60 + $18 = $78). In one year, she saved $162 ($240 - $78) by using a checking account instead of a check-cashing store.

lang.Spanish: Derechos preferentes (warrants) sobre compra de acciones

English.defintion: Offers to buy and sell shares at specific prices.

The repurchase by the firm of outstanding common stock in the marketplace; desired effects of stock repurchases are that they either enhance shareholder value or help to discourage an unfriendly takeover.
Computerized system that flags unusual volume or price changes.
Financial agent who assists investors with buying and selling financial assets.

When you buy stocks (shares), you become part owner of the company. If the company does well, you might receive periodic dividends. Dividends are part of a company's profits it gives back to you when you own stock in the company. If the company does poorly, you might lose your money.
A method commonly used to lower the market price of a firm's stock by increasing the number of shares belonging to each shareholder.
The owners of a corporation, whose ownership, or equity, is evidenced by either common stock or preferred stock.
Annual report that publicly owned corporations must provide to stockholders; it summarizes and documents the firm's financial activities during the past year.
Order to buy or sell a certain quantity of a security at a specified price or better, but only after a specified price has been reached.
Stop order to sell a long positon at a specified price that is below the current market price.
Market order to buy or sell a certain quantity of a security if a specified price is reached or passed.
Purchase of a put and sale of a call on the same security.

English.word: Straight-line Method of amortizing Bond Discount or Premium

lang.Spanish: Método do de amortización en línea recta de los bonos descontados

English.defintion: Paying bills as late as possible without damaging the firm's credit rating.
Exercise price.
Increase in the amount of foreign currency that can be purchased for $1.
Premise that stock prices reflecta ll public information and nonpublic information.
Ranked as less important.
Claims are not satisfied until those of the creditors holding certain (senior) debts have been fully satisfied.
In a bond indenture, the stipulation that subsequent creditors agree to wait until all claims of the senior debt are satisfied.
Cash outlays that have already been made (past outlays) and therefore have no effect on the cash flows relevant to a current decision.
Stock that carries with it multiple votes per share rather than the single vote per share typically given on regular shares of common stock..
Arrangments whereby two companies agree to lend to each other on different terms.
Options to engage in a specific interest rate swap on or before a specific date.
Lead investment bank in a syndicate.
A payoff derived from holding nonoption securities that is identical with a put or call strategy.
Return volatility tied to the overall market.
Treasury bills (mature in less than one year).
Treasury bonds (mature in 10 to 30 years).
Treasury notes (mature in 1 to 10 years).
The desired optimal mix of debt and equity financing that most firms attempt to maintain.

A dividend policy under which the firm attempts to pay out a certain percentage of earnings as a stated dollar dividend and adjusts that dividend towerd a target payout as proven earnings increases occur.

lang.Spanish: Razón de pago de dividendos objetivo

English.defintion: Either book or market value weights based on desired capital structure proportions.

English.word: Tax on sale of old asset
English.defintion: Tax that depends on the relationship among the old asset's sale price, initial purchase price, and book value, and on existing government tax rules.

lang.Spanish: Impuesto sobre la venta de un activo antiguo

English.defintion: Study of historical price and volumen information to forecast future prices.
Describes a firm that is unable to pay its bills as they come due.
Shares in companies at the vanguard of important new innovations.

English.word: Un servicio bancario que le permite
English.defintion: A bank service which allows you to: •Check account balances •Transfer money between accounts •Obtain account history, such as most recent deposits or withdrawals •Stop payment on a check •Obtain information on branch hours or other information •Report a lost, stolen, or damaged credit, debit, or ATM card

The teller is the person behind the counter who takes money, answers questions, cashes checks, or refers you to the person who can help you. Tellers are the main contact people at the bank. You can go to any teller in the bank.
A formal offer to purchase a given number of shares of a firm's stock at a specified price.
The relationship between the interest rate or rate of return and the time to maturity.

lang.Spanish: Estructura de términos de las tasas de interés

English.defintion: The after-tax nonoperating cash flow occurring in the final year of a project. It is usually attributable to liquidation of the project.
Sensitivity of option value to a change in time.
A thrift is a savings bank or savings and loan association that is similar to a bank. Thrifts were created to promote homeownership and must have a majority of their assets in housing-related loans.
Unique one-, two-, three-, or four-letter code for any company.
Unique stock identifier with one to five letters.

lang.Spanish: Tasa de rendimiento de ajuste de tiempo

English.defintion: Beta estimation problem derived from the fact that beta estimates depend on the data interval studied.
A horizontal line on which time zero appears at the leftmost end and future periods are marked from left to right; can be used to depict investment cash flows.
Measures the firm's ability to make contractual interest payment; sometines called the interest coverage ratio.

lang.Spanish: Razón de la capacidad de pago de intereses

English.defintion: Data points over time.
Evaluation of the firm's financial performance over time using financial ratio analysis.
Simulataneous purchase and sale of options on the same underlying stock but with different expiration dates.
Speculative value that diminishes over time.
The title indicates the right of ownership in the property.
Title insurance protects the buyer and lender against losses arising from disputes over the ownership of property.
Indicates the efficiency with which the firm uses its assets to generate sales.
The sum of order costs and carrying costs of inventory.
The potential use of fixed costs, both operating and financial, to magnify the effect of changes in sales on the firm's earnings per share.
The sum of dividends, interest income, and capital gains or capital losses.
The combination of a security's nondiversifiable risk and diversifiable risk.
A townhouse is one of a row of houses connected by common side walls.
Excess value of imports over exports.
Prices that subsidiaries charge each other for the goods and services traded between them.

The firm's chief financial manager, who is responsible for the firm's financial activities, such as financial planning and fund raising, making capital expenditure decisions, and managing cash, credit, the pension fund, and foreign exchange.
Treasury obligations with maturities of one year or less.
Treasury obligations with maturities of 10 years or more.
Treasury bonds whose par value is adjusted semiannually for inflation, as measured by the CPI.
Treasury obligations with maturities of more than 1 year but less than 10 years.
The number of shares of outstanding stock that have been repurchased by the firm.

A secured short-term loan against inventory under which the lender advances 80 to 100 percent of the cost of the borrower's relatively expensive inventory items in exchange for the borrower's promise to repay the lender, with accrued interest, immediately after the sale of each item of collateral.

lang.Spanish: Préstamo garantizado con inventario en fideicomiso

English.defintion: A paid individual, corporation, or comercial bank trust department that acts as the third party to a bond indenture and can take specified actions on behalf of the bondholders if the terms of the indenture are violated.
A common measure of a mutual fund's trading activity.
Unsophisticated inventory-monitoring technique that is typically applied to C group items and involves reordering inventory when one of two bins is empty.

lang.Spanish: Método de inventario de dos depósitos

English.defintion: Short-term IOUs issued by the U.S. Treasury; considered the risk-free asset.
Describes two series that lack any interaction and therefore have a correlation coefficient close to zero.
Stock sold at a price below its current market price, P0.
A stock priced below its true economic value.
Investment bank that endorses and sponsors a company's new securities.
Investment banker's allocation of the new shares.
The role of the investment banker in bearing the risk of reselling, at a profit, the securities purchased from an issuing corporation at an agreed-on price.
A group formed by an investment banker to share the financial risk associated with underwriting new securities.

lang.Spanish: Método de depreciación de las unidades producidas

English.defintion: The financial situation in which a firm is able to accept all independent projects that provide an aceptable return.
The condition of a sole proprietorship (or general partnership) allowing the owner's total wealth to be taken to satisfy creditors.
Increase in fund value caused by a rise in the value of fund investments.
Debt backed only by the reputation, credit record, and financial stability or the corporation.
Short term financing obtained without pledging specific assets as collateral.

lang.Spanish: Financiamiento no garantizado a corto plazo

English.defintion: Return volatility specific to an individual company.

Savings bonds are one type of Treasury securities. They are a long-term investment option backed by the full faith and credit of the U.S. government. Purchasing these bonds is an easy way to save small amounts of money and are often purchased for a child's education; however, they may be used for any purpose. Savings bonds can be purchased at a financial institution for as little as $25 or through payroll deduction.

lang.Spanish: Bonos de ahorro de los Estados Unidos

English.defintion: U.S. Treasury securities are debt instruments. When you purchase a Treasury security, you are loaning money to the government. Treasury securities are backed by the full faith and credit of the U.S. government, which means the government guarantees interest and principal payments will be paid on time. Treasury securities include: •Savings bonds, which can earn interest for up to 30 years, but can be cashed after 6 months. •Treasury bills, which mature in one year or less from their issue date. •Treasury notes, which mature in more than a year, but not more than 10 years from the issue date. •Treasury bonds, which mature in more than 10 years from the issue date. Treasury bills, notes, and bonds are transferable, which means you can buy or sell them in the securities market. You can buy Treasury bills, notes, and bonds for a minimum of $1,000.

lang.Spanish: Valores de Tesorería de los Estados Unidos

English.defintion: The process that links risk and return to determine the worth of an asset.
Investment approach that concentrates on securities considered to be temporarily undervalued or unpopular.
Investors who seek out-of-favor stocks selling at a discount to the overall market.
Model used when short-term growth rates are not expected to persist in the long run.

A variable rate loan has an interest rate that might change during any period of the loan as written in the contract (loan agreement). Variable rate mortgages are often referred as adjustable rate mortgages (ARMs).
Privately raised external equity capital used to fund early-stage firms with attractive growth prospects.
Providers of venture capital; typically, formal businesses that maintain strong oversight over the firms thay invest in and that have clearly defined exit strategies.
A secured short-term loan against inventory under which the lender receives control of the pledged inventory collateral, which is stored by a designated warehousing company on the lender's behalf.

lang.Spanish: Préstamo garantizado con inventario de almacén

English.defintion: Decrease in the amount of foreign currency that can be purchased for $1.
Premise that current prices reflect all stock market information.

English.word: Weighted average cost of capital (WACC), ka
English.defintion: Reflects the expected average future cost of funds over the long run; found by weighting the cost of each specific type of capital by its proportion in the firm's capital structure.

lang.Spanish: Costo de capital promedio ponderado (WACC), ka

English.defintion: The firm's weighted average cost of capital (WACC) associated with its next dollar of total new financing.
An electronic communication that, via bookkeeping entries, removes funds from the payer's bank and deposits them in the payee's bank.
A wire transfer is a method of electronically transferring money from one bank to another.

A withdrawal is the process of taking money from your bank account. You do this by writing a check, using an ATM, or by giving a teller a withdrawal slip. A withdrawal slip looks similar to a deposit slip, except you are taking money out rather than adding money to your account. You need to be sure you do not withdraw more money than you have in your account. If you do, you will be overdrawn, or bounce a check, and be charged a fee.
Current assets, which represent the portion of investment that circulates from one form to another in the ordinary conduct of business.
Sellers who are obligated to exercise the option at the holder's request.
Foreign bond issued in the United States by a non-U.S. borrower and denominated in dollars.

A graph of the relationship between the debt's remaining time to maturity (x axis) and its yield to maturity (y axis); it shows the pattern of annual returns on debts of equal quality and differst maturities. Graphically depicts the term structure of interest rates.
Difference in yield for bonds with the same term to maturity but different credit risks.
Investor return over the period from the settlement day to the security's repurchase by the issuer.
Annual rate of return earned on a debt security pruchased on a given day and held to maturity.
Issued with no (zero) or a very low coupon (stated interest) rate and sold at a large discount from par.

lang.Spanish: Bonos cupón cero (o de cupón bajo

English.defintion: A disbursement account that always has an end-of-day balance of zero because the firm deposits money to cover checks drawn on the account only as they are presented for payment each day.
An approach to dividend valuation that assumes a constant, nongrowing dividend stream.\
A constant-return portfolio.
Transaction in which the buyer's gain is the seller's loss, and vice versa.

Spanish.defintion: Gastos de mercadeo. Es el costo cobrado por promocion, mercadeo y ventes en fondos mutuos.

Los planes 401(k) son planes de jubilación que algunas empresas privadas ofrecen a sus empleados. Un plan 403(b) plan es similar a un 401(k), pero se ofrece a empleados de algunas organizaciones sin fines de lucro. En ambos tipos de planes, usted elige deducir parte de su cheque de pago y destinarlon a la estrategia de inversión que usted diseña. El plan le permite elegir diferentes tipos de inversiones, según el riesgo que desea aceptar. El dinero que usted coloca en la cuenta disminuye su ingreso sujeto a impuestos. El empleador generalmente iguala una parte de su contribución, algunas veces hasta el 50%. Los fondos crecen sin pagar impuestos hasta que se retira el dinero durante la jubilación.
Técnica de administración de inventarios que divide el inventario en tres grupos: A, B, C, en orden descendente de importancia y nivel de supervisión, con base in la inversión monetaria de cada uno.

Spanish.word: Capacidad de cumplimiento del servicio de la deuda
Spanish.defintion: Capacidad de una empresa de hacer los pagos requeridos se acuerdo con un programa durante la vigencia de la deuda.
Método de costos que incluye todos los costos de fabricación - materiales directos, mano de obra directa, y costos indirectos fijos y variables - como parte del costo de un producto terminado.
Método de depreciación en el cual en los primeros años de vida del activo su depreciación se efectúa en grandes cantidades disminuyendo su cargo de depreciación en los últimos anos.
Evaluación de las propuestas del gasto de capital para determinar si cumplen el criterio mínimo de aceptación de la empresa.
Es el lugar donde se anotan los aumentos y disminuciones de cada partida de una transacción de negocios.

Persona capacitada para registrar las operaciones que se realizan, implementar sistemas a seguir en el registro de las operaciones de la empresa, proporcionar informes o documentos que reflejen la situación financiera de la empresa, así como tomar las resoluciones que se requieren en la administración de la empresa.
Obligaciones o deudas que resultan por la compra de bienes o servicios a crédito.
Administración por parte de la empresa del tiempo que pasa entre la compra de materia prima y el envío del pago al proveedor.
Monto que los clientes le deben al negocio por concepto de venta de bienes o servicios que la empresa les otorga a crédito.

Antes de abrir una cuenta, la mayoría de los bancos estudiarán sus antecedentes en el uso de cuentas corrientes mediante compañías como TeleCheck o ChexSystems. Algunos bancos revisarán el informe completo sobre su historia de crédito para determinar el nivel de riesgo. La información sobre cuentas se obtiene de instituciones financieras. Si tiene antecedentes de cheques rechazados o uso incorrecto de sus cuentas, las instituciones financieras tal vez no le permitan abrir una cuenta.
En la preparación de los estados financieros, los ingresos se reconocen al momento de la venta y los gastos al momento de incurrir en ellos.
Obligaciones por servicios recibidos que aun no se han pagado.
Monto que los clientes le deben al negocio por concepto de venta de bienes o servicios que la empresa les otorga a crédito.
Ingresos devengados durante un periodo contable mismos que al cierre del ejercicio permanecen sin registrar debido a que el pago aun no ha sido recibido.
Cantidad total de depreciación registrada disminuyendo el valor del activo fijo durante el numero de anos asignado a la vida de servicio del activo en libros.

Retiro electrónico, autorizado previamente, que hace la cámara de compensación automatizada (ACH) de la cuenta del cliente para depositarlo en la cuenta del beneficiario a través de una liquidación entre bancos.
Miden la velocidad con la que varia cuentas se convierten en ventas o efectivo, es decir, ingresos o egresos.
Todos los costos ejecutivos, organizacionales y de oficina asociados con la administración general de una organización.

Spanish.word: Beneficios a ganancias después de impuestos
Spanish.defintion: Cantidad neta del flujo de efectivo ganada por una organización después de habérsele descontado los impuestos correspondientes. La cantidad neta se determina multiplicando el efectivo recibido por (1 - tasa de impuesto).

Cantidad neta del flujo de efectivo resultante de un gasto en efectivo deducible de impuestos después de habérsele descontado los impuestos correspondientes. La cantidad se determina multiplicando el gasto en efectivo por (1 - tasa de impuesto).

Spanish.word: Beneficios después de impuestos de la venta de un activo antiguo
Spanish.defintion: La diferencia entre los beneficios de la venta de un activo antiguo y cualquier impuesto o devolución de impuestos aplicable relacionado con su venta.

lang.English: After-tax proceeds from sale of old asset

Spanish.defintion: Costos pagados por los accionistas para minimizar los problemas de agencia.
Posibilidad de que los administradores antepongan los objetivos personales a los corporativos.
E strategia de financiamiento bajo la cual la empresa financia sus requerimientos estacionales con deuda a corto plazo y sus requerimientos permanentes con deuda a largo plazo.

Spanish.word: Determinación de la antigüedad de las cuentas por cobrar
Spanish.defintion: Técnica de supervisión de crédito que utiliza un calendario que indica los porcentajes del balance del total de cuentas por cobrar que han estado pendientes durante periodos especificados de tiempo.

Rendimiento abnormal para obtener el rendimiento de tasa requerida por el modelo de CAPM. El rendimiento abnormal puede ser positivo si el alfa es mayor que zero o negativo si el alfa es menos que zero

Derechos emitidos por los bancos estadounidenses que representan propiedad sobre acciones de una empresa extranjera mantenidas en deposito en el mercado extranjero por el banco estadounidense y emitidas en dólares para los inversionistas estadounidenses.

La Tercera Bolsa de acciones mas grande de los Estados Unidos. En 2008, fue comprada por al NYSE y se convirtió en el NYSE Amex Equities en 2009. The AMEX es ubicada en New York City and absorbe cerca de 10 por ciento de todos las acciones en los Estados Unidos.
Baja de valor que sufre el activo intangible y su aplicación del gasto en proporción al valor y al tiempo.
Inversionistas individuales acaudalados que no operan como una compañía sino que invierten en impresas promisorias que apenas inician, a cambio de una parte de las acciones de dichas empresas.
Requisito de que, durante un cierto numero de días al año, los prestatarios de una línea de crédito tengan un saldo de cero sobre el préstamo (es decir, no deban nada al banco).

Tasa anual nominal de interés, que se obtiene multiplicando la tasa periódica por el numero de periodos en un año, que se debe dar a conocer a los usuarios de tarjetas de crédito y prestamos como resultado de las “leyes de la verdad en los prestamos”.

La APR es una medida del costo de su préstamo expresado como una tasa porcentual anual, como 10% u 11%. La APR es la tasa de interés que se le cobra, expresada como tasa anual. Si piensa mantener un saldo en su cuenta de la tarjeta de crédito, es conveniente tener una APR baja. Si piensa pagar sus facturas completamente todos los meses, será más importante comparar cargo anual y otros cargos.
Tasa anual efectiva de interés que los bancos deben dar a conocer a los consumidores por sus productos de ahorros como resultado de las “leyes de la verdad en los ahorros”.

Spanish.word: Rendimiento porcentual anual (APY, por sus siglas en inglés)
Spanish.defintion: APY es el interés que usted ganará anualmente expresado como un porcentaje. El APY incluye el efecto de la composición. Al comparar cuentas diferentes, debe comparar los APY de los productos de ahorro, no las tasas de interés. Cuanto más alto es el APY, más alto es el interés que recibirá.

Serie de flujos de efectivo periódicos iguales durante un periodo determinado. Estos flujos pueden ser flujos positivos de efectivo de rendimientos obtenidos en inversiones, o flujos negativos de efectivo de fondos invertidos para obtener rendimientos futuros.
Anualidad para la cual el flujo de efectivo ocurre al inicio de cada periodo.
Una opinion professional del valor en el Mercado. Una opinion sobre el valor monetario de un activo.
Costos incurridos para identificar los productos defectuosos antes de ser enviados al cliente.
Ganancias retenidas asignadas a un uso especial donde se informa a los accionistas que estas ganancias no estarán disponibles para el reparto de dividendos.

En economía y finanzas, el arbitraje es la práctica de tomar ventaja de una diferencia de precio entre dos o más mercados: realizar una combinación de transacciones complementarias que capitalizan el imbalance de precios. La utilidad se logra debido a la diferencia de precios de mercado. Por medio de arbitraje, los participantes en el mercado pueden lograr una utilidad instantánea libre de riesgo. El proceso de compra y venta de productos indenticos, tal como tipos de cambio, acciones, bonos, y otros instrumentos financieros, en varios mercados con el propósito de tener una ganancia. Arbitraje es visto como una transacion sin riesgo.

Spanish.word: Teoria de varios factores de Mercado
Spanish.defintion: Un modelo de precios de actives de varios factores que permite a los betas del Mercado a representar solamente a uno delos muchos factores de riesgo de la firma.
La suma del rendimiento de las inversions dividido por el numero de periodos de las seguridads.
Aplicación que presenta un negocio en el estado en el que se incorpora.
Contrato escrito que se utiliza para establecer formalmente una asociación empresarial.
Numero de valores ofrecido por vendedores de activos
Un bien es toda cosa propiedad de una persona u organización que tiene valor monetario.
El activo representa todos los bienes y derechos que son propiedad del negocio.
Proceso de diversificar un portfolio de inversions atraves de varias categorias de activos, tales como acciones, bonos, y efectivo.
Situación en la que los administradores de una empresa tienen mas información sobre las operaciones y prospectos futuros que los inversionistas.
Venta publica por medio de compra abierta.

Examen de los registros contables y reportes financieros de una entidad, para así comprobar si están apegados a los principios de contabilidad generalmente aceptados y que tan veraz y oportuna es la información que presentan los estados financieros.
Numero de acciones ordinarias que el acta constitutiva de una empresa permite que ésta emita.
El máximo numero de acciones que el estado autoriza a la empresa.

Esta es una máquina donde puede depositar, retirar o transferir dinero de una cuenta a otra las 24 horas del día. El uso de un cajero automático requiere una tarjeta emitida por el banco y un número de identificación personal (PIN). Un PIN es una contraseña especial o un conjunto de números para usar su tarjeta de débito o de cajero automático. El PIN se utiliza por razones de seguridad y para garantizar que nadie más pueda tener acceso a su cuenta. Usted puede utilizar el cajero automático para muchos servicios, pero algunas veces se cobra una tarifa. La mayoría de las personas utilizan el cajero automático para obtener dinero de su cuenta. Si usted utiliza el cajero automático de otro banco, tal vez se le cobre una tarifa adicional. En general, los depósitos solo pueden hacerse en el cajero automático de su banco.
Numero promedio de días de ventas en un inventario.
Promedio de tiempo requerido para la cobranza de cuentas por cobrar.
Promedio de tiempo requerido para el pago de cuentas por pagar.
Impuestos de una empresa, divididos entre sus ingresos gravables.
Método de costos que incluye todos los costos de fabricación - materiales directos, mano de obra directa, y costos indirectos fijos y variables - como parte del costo de un producto terminado.
Comision pagado cuando un fondo es vendido.
Analisis mirando el pasado.
Cuentas por cobrar que no han sido liquidadas, cuyo saldo es un gasto de ventas a crédito.
Saldo es la cantidad de dinero que tiene en su cuenta bancaria.

Spanish.word: Método para el Cálculo del Saldo
Spanish.defintion: Esto determinará cómo se calcula el interés. Son varios los métodos. El más común es el saldo diario medio.

Documento contable que presenta la situación financiera de un negocio en una fecha determinada, y muestra clara y detalladamente el valor de cada una de las propiedades (activos) y obligaciones (pasivos) así como el importe de capital.

Una hipoteca balloon es un pago grande al finalizar el plazo de su préstamo. A menudo ocurre después de una serie de pagos mensuales bajos. Una hipoteca balloon generalmente ofrece tasas muy bajas durante un período inicial de tiempo (generalmente 5, 7 ó 10 años). Al finalizar el período se debe todo el saldo. Muchos prestatarios pagan el saldo mediante la refinanciación de la hipoteca.
Un banco es una entidad que ofrece un lugar para guardar su dinero y emplea el dinero para hacer más dinero. Los bancos le ofrecen diferentes servicios a cambio de su dinero.

Cantidad de intereses cargados por el banco cuando el banco acepta el cobro de pagares descontados de cliente. También se dice de los intereses pagados por anticipados cuando el banco otorga un préstamo.
Análisis que expresa la diferencia entre el saldo de la cuenta de bancos en libros y el saldo en los estados de cuenta bancario.
El tipo mas sencillo de distribución de probabilidades; muestra solo un numero limitado de resultados y probabilidades asociadas para un evento dado.
Representa 1
La posibilidad the un cambio adverso en el Mercado de futures—es el precio de Mercado corriente.
Un studio cognitivo de los errors producido por acciones y decisiones psycologicas.
Tipo de análisis seccional en el que se comparan los valores de las razones de la empresa con los de un competidor clave o grupo de competidores que desea emular.
Medida relativa del riesgo no diversificable. Es un índice del grado de movimiento del rendimiento de un activo en respuesta al cambio en el rendimiento de mercado.
La diferencia entre los precios del bid y ask que representa el costo o la ganancia del inversionista.

Spanish.word: Argumento mas vale pájaro en mano
Spanish.defintion: Creencia, en apoyo de la teoría de la relevancia de dividendos, de que los inversionistas consideran que los dividendos actuales son menos riesgosos que los dividendos o ganancias de capital futuros.
Formula usada para calcular los precios del put y call en las opciones.
Grupo elegido por los accionistas de la empresa u que tiene la máxima autoridad para guiar los asuntos de la corporación y establecer una política general.
Instrumento de deuda a largo plazo utilizado por las empresas y el gobierno para obtener grandes sumas de dinero, por lo general de varios grupos de prestamistas.

Cuando compra un bono, básicamente está prestando dinero a una empresa o al gobierno durante un período determinado de tiempo, denominado plazo. El certificado del bono promete que la empresa o el gobierno le devolverá el dinero a usted en una fecha determinada con una tasa fija de interés.

Spanish.word: Tasa de Voucher de un Bono
Spanish.defintion: La tasa de interes de un bono expresado como un percentage del valor par.
Documento legal que especifica los derechos de los tenedores de bonos y las obligaciones de la corporación emisora.
Individuos e insituciones que compran bonos por entrada de interes y ganancias de capital a largo plazo.
Es el fondo que establece el de proveer del pago en efectivo del bono al bonista en el momento del vencimiento.
Venta y compra simultanea de valores de ingresos fijos para alcanzar un plan establecido de inversions.

Spanish.word: Libro de entradas o asiento final
Spanish.defintion: Libro en donde se registran las cantidades del libro de diario.
Valor contable estricto de un activo, calculado restando su depreciación acumulada de su costo histórico.

Cantidad de acciones ordinarias que se recibiría si todos los activos de la empresa se vendieran a su valor en libros (contable) exacto y los beneficios que quedaran después de pagar todas las obligaciones (entre ellas las acciones preferentes) se dividieran entre los accionistas comunes.
Ponderaciones que utilizan valores contables para medir la proporción de cada tipo de capital en la estructura financiera de la empresa.
Es la maquina o el proceso que limita la salida total por no estar operando a la capacidad.
Un gerente de sucursal es la persona que supervisa las operaciones del banco y ayuda a solucionar problemas que no pueden ser solucionados por otros empleados del banco.
El numero de anos donde la inversion inicial puede ser recuperado a traves del augment de ingresos.

Nivel del nuevo financiamiento total en el que se eleva el costo de uno de los componentes del financiamiento, provocando un desplazamiento ascendente en el costo de capital marginal ponderado (WMCC).
Indica el nivel de operaciones necesarias para cubrir todos los costos operativos y la rentabilidad asociada con los diversos niveles de ventas.
Un corredor hipotecario ayuda a un posible prestatario a comparar para obtener la mejor tasa y las mejores condiciones para la financiación del crédito hipotecario.
La tasa de interes cobrado por corredores a inversionistas que toman prestado para inverter usando la deuda como margen.
Informe formal de las planes futuros, usualmente expresados en términos monetarios.
Proceso de planear acciones comerciales futuras y expresarlas en planes formales.
Diferencia entre el costo fijo indirecto real, incurrido durante el periodo y los costos fijos indirectos presupuestados dentro del presupuesto.
Compra de una opcion call a bajo precio y simultaneamente la venta de una opcion call a un precio masalto, del mismo activo a law misma fecha de expiracion.
Riesgo de que una empresa no pueda cubrir sus costos operativos.
Intercambio de mercancías, servicios o derechos monetarios entre dos entidades económicas con el fin de recibir beneficios económicos.
Una orden de compra que sera retenida hasta que el precio en el Mercado subea un precio especifacado.
Extra comision pagada por el comprador de un valor.
El tiemp estipulado antes que un bono pueda ser pagado.
Una provicion estipulada en contrato del bono que permite a la firma que emite el bono a redemir el bono antes de la fecha de expiracion.

Spanish.word: Bonos redimibles antes de su vencimiento
Spanish.defintion: Bono que permite al emisor pagar la obligación antes del vencimiento, dando el aviso de rescate en la forma especificada en la escritura de emisión.

Spanish.word: Acciones preferentes redimibles a su vencimiento
Spanish.defintion: Acciones preferentes de la compañía emisora, opta por retirarlas pagando una cantidad especifica a los accionistas preferentes mas dividendos atrasados.
Característica incluida en casi todas las emisiones de bonos corporativos, que da al usuario la oportunidad de recomprar los bonos a un precio de compensación establecido antes del vencimiento.
Cantidad por la que el precio de compensación de un bono excede su valor nominal.
Precio establecido al que se podría readquirir un bono, mediante una cláusula de cancelación, antes del vencimiento.
Cheques pagados por el banco y deducidos de la cuenta del cliente durante el mes, son llamados cheques pagados porque han sido sellados indicando que han sido pagados.

Spanish.word: Modelo Para Valorar Activos de Capital
Spanish.defintion: Modelo usado para determiner el valor o precio de activos en un mercado de capital eficiente.

Los topes son disposiciones de un crédito hipotecario a tasa variable, que limitan el monto de la tasa de interés que puede cambiar en cada período de ajuste o durante el plazo del préstamo. Un tope de pago limita cuánto puede aumentar o disminuir el pago pendiente del préstamo.
Fondos a largo plazo de una empresa; todos los rubros que aparecen en el lado derecho del balance general de la empresa excepto el pasivo circulante.

Spanish.word: Modelo de valuación de activos de capital [CAPM]
Spanish.defintion: La teoría básica que vincula el riesgo y rendimiento de todos los activos.
Presupuesto que cubre la adquisición de terreno, edificios y artículos de activo fijo; este presupuesto puede tener un lapso de 30 años o mas en el futuro.
Proceso de evaluación y selección de inversiones a largo plazo que concuerdan con las metas de la empresa de maximizar la riqueza del propietario.

Spanish.word: Proceso de preparación del presupuesto de capital
Spanish.defintion: Cinco pasos distintos pero interrelacionados: generación de propuestas, revisión y análisis, toma de decisiones, implementación y seguimiento.
Perdida de la participación en el Mercado como resultado de la tecnología obsoleta de productos y operaciones.
Desembolso de fondos hecho por la empresa, que se espera que produzca beneficios durante un periodo de mas de un año.
Cantidad por la cual el precio de venta de un activo supera el precio de compra inicial del activo.

Arrendamiento que esencialmente tiene el mismo efecto entre el arrendador y el arrendatario en la transacción de compra en donde el arrendatario es como si obtuviese un préstamo para la compañía del bien arrendado; el arrendamiento se capitalizara si reúne criterios establecidos.
Mercado que permite que proveedores y demandantes de fondos a largo plazo hagan transacciones.
Situación financiera en la que una empresa solo tiene una cantidad fija de efectivo disponible para gastos de capital, y numerosos proyectos compiten por ese efectivo.
Representa la participación que tienen las accionistas sobre los activos de una empresa.
Combinación de deuda y capital a largo plazo mantenida por la empresa.

Spanish.word: Valor neto en libros de bonos a pagar
Spanish.defintion: Valor neto de los bonos en que se registraran en los libros; equivale al valor del bono menos el descuento amortizado, o mas la prima amortizada.

lang.English: Carrying Amount of the Bonds Payable

Spanish.word: Valor neto en libros del arrendamiento
Spanish.defintion: Diferencia entre la suma del saldo remanente de pagos menos el descuento sin amortizar.

Spanish.word: Valor neto en libros de documentos
Spanish.defintion: Es el valor del documento menos el descuento sin amortizar.
Costos variables por unidad de mantener un articulo en inventario durante un periodo específico.
Constituido por el total de moneda en curso legal y sus equivalentes, aceptados por el banco para deposito, mas el saldo que se haya depositado en el banco.
Reconoce ingresos y gastos solo con respecto a flujos positivos y negativos de efectivo reales.
Dinero que se paga a la administración por lograr ciertas metas de desempeño.
Estado de los flujos positivos y negativos de efectivo planeados de la empresa, que se utiliza para estivar sus requerimientos de efectivo a corto plazo.
Proceso utilizado por las empresas para tener servicios de cajas de seguridad y otros depósitos en un banco, llamado banco de concentración.
Cantidad de tiempo que los recursos de una empresa se mantienen invertidos; se calcula restando del ciclo operativo el periodo promedio de pago.
Todos los egresos de efectivo de la empresa durante un periodo financiero dado.
Deducción de un porcentaje del precio de compra; se aplica al cliente a crédito que paga su cuenta dentro de un tiempo especificado.

Spanish.word: Periodo de descuento por pronto pago
Spanish.defintion: El numero de días después del inicio del periodo de crédito durante el cual se puede aprovechar el descuento por pronto pago.
Es la inversión pronta a vencer y que se convertirá en efectivo a la cantidad establecida y su valor en el mercado es relativamente insensitiva a los cambios de intereses.
Cuenta de resultados en donde se registran los faltantes y sobrantes de caja chica por falta de comprobantes o por errores en el manejo.
Todos los flujos positivos de efectivo de una empresa en un periodo financiero dado.
Instrumentos o inversions al corto plazo, menos de un ano.

Los CD son cuentas en las que usted deja su dinero durante un período determinado de tiempo, como seis meses, uno, dos o cinco años, denominado plazo. Generalmente obtendrá una tasa de interés más alta que en una cuenta de ahorro común. Cuanto más tiempo promete mantener el dinero en el CD, más alta es la tasa de interés. Asegúrese de tener en cuenta sus necesidades de efectivo antes de abrir un CD porque pagará una penalidad si retira el dinero temprano.

Spanish.word: Cambio en el capital de trabajo neto
Spanish.defintion: Diferencia entre un cambio en los activos circulantes y un cambio en los pasivos circulantes.

Una cuenta corriente es una cuenta que le permite girar cheques para pagar deudas o comprar mercancías. La institución financiera retira el dinero de su cuenta y lo paga a la persona a cuyo nombre se giró el cheque. La institución financiera le envía a usted un informe mensual de los depósitos realizados y los cheques girados.
Es el balance general que muestra los activos y pasivos agrupados en subdivisiones significativos.
El tiempo entre el deposito de un pago y el momento en que los fondos erogables están a disposición de la empresa.
Argumento de que una empresa atrae accionistas cuyas preferencias por el pago y estabilidad de dividendos corresponden al patrón y estabilidad de pagos de la empresa misma.
Todos las acciones ordinarias de una empresa que son propiedad de un grupo pequeño de inversionistas (como una familia).
Los gastos de cierre son varios cargos en relación con la transferencia de propiedad. El prestamista debe comunicarle estos gastos a usted.

Una cuenta de club es un tipo de cuenta de ahorro que usted “abre” para ahorrar dinero para un fin especial, como días festivos o vacaciones familiares. Las cuentas de clubes generalmente requieren que usted haga depósitos periódicamente.
